Dear Megan Zambiasi:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Please review the
enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In the event
that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager at 616-552-3662.
Sincerely,
Deborah Will, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions
Section
Description (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(iii)Threats of restraint, seclusion, punishment, or otherwise
suggesting physical or emotional harm to a youth.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff verbally threatened a youth.
Investigation I notified Foster Care Worker that I was assigned this
investigation. She expressed no additional concerns regarding
the facility.
I notified Rights Officer of the allegation.
I reviewed the facility’s history of licensing rule violations.
I interviewed Complainant, who is a staff member, with Rights
Officer present on 6/13/23. She has worked at the facility for over
four years. On 6/9/23, Complainant said she heard and saw
Youth C cussing at Team Leader and grab Team Leader’s arm.
Team Leader pulled her arm away. Youth C warned Team
Leader, “Run up, get done up,” meaning she challenged Team
Leader to a fight. Team Leader responded back to Youth C, “Run
up, get done up. This job doesn’t pay me enough fucking money.”
Then Team Leader exited the building.
I interviewed Youth C with Rights Officer present. She said Team
Leader walked her from school to Beata Hall and “buddied” her
“hard.” Vista Maria utilizes a “buddy system” which involves youth
interlocking arms with staff or another youth when moving one
building to another. “I grabbed Team Leader’s arm. We buddied.
Team Leader told my supervisor. I showed Supervisor what
Team Leader did to my arm. I approached Team Leader and
yelled. Team Leader said, ‘Run up, get done up. I don’t care
about this job.’” Supervisor and Complainant had to hold both of
us back.” Then Complainant escorted Team Leader out of the
building.
2

I interviewed Supervisor on 6/15/23 with Rights Officer present.
She has worked at the facility for 13 years. Supervisor said she
heard Youth C and Team Leader “going back and forth.” Team
Leader let her know Youth C had snatched her arm away from her
while transporting to the building. Youth C grabbed Team
Leader’s arm to demonstrate to Supervisor how Team Leader
buddied her. Team Leader told Youth C not to touch her. “I got
between Youth C and Team Leader so Team Leader could walk
away. Team Leader said “Run up, get done up. This job doesn’t
pay enough to deal with this.” Supervisor said Team Leader
showed no signs of aggression toward Youth C.
I interviewed Team Leader on 6/22/23. She has worked at the
facility over 12 years, usually works in another building and said
she had no contact with Youth C since the incident. There were
no disciplinary write-ups in Team Leader’s personnel file.
On the day of this incident, Team Leader said she was helping out
at the school when school staff asked her to transport Youth C to
Beata Hall. “When I scooped my arm in to ‘buddy,’ Youth C
snatched her arm away. She got loud and was cussing. I asked
her to buddy with another resident, but she refused. I said, “We
can’t go then.” Youth C reluctantly agreed to “buddy” with me.
“On the way to Beata, Youth C was physically resistant, pulling on
me. I asked her to stop. She continued. Outside Beata’s door,
Youth C yanked her left arm away and elbowed me in the chest.
We entered the foyer. I talked to Supervisor. Youth C came to
the office door protesting and arguing. Youth C grabbed my right
arm. I yanked it and told her not to touch or grab me. She said,
‘Get your finger out of my face.’ Youth C made a sudden
movement causing me to flinch. I was already around the corner
and said, ‘Please don’t run up or you’ll end up getting done up.’”
I asked Team Leader what she meant by that statement. She
said she meant she would “protect herself.” Team Leader denied
cursing and recognized how her statement could be viewed as
threatening. She apologized for her response and said she has
been assaulted by youths on four different occasions. “I got
sucked in,” she admitted.
Analysis Team Leader admitted she verbally responded to Youth C in a
threatening manner.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
2023C0000229 intake 2/8/23, CAP approved 3/23/23
3

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.

sir_summary.summary: A staff Team Leader at Vista Maria verbally threatened a youth during a confrontation, telling the youth 'Run up, get done up' and making a statement about the job not paying enough, which constituted a prohibited intervention. The investigation, which included interviews with the youth, complainant, supervisor, and the Team Leader herself, substantiated the allegation, and the Team Leader admitted her statement could be viewed as threatening. This was a repeat violation of rules against threats of harm, indicating a failure of prior corrective actions to ensure compliance.
